tn.text: This is the first of five urgent warnings the author gives.
Here "we" refers to the author and includes his audience. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: so that we do not drift away
tn.text: Believing in God's word less and less is spoken of as if a boat were drifting away on the water from where it should be. AT: "so that we do not gradually stop believing it" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: For if the message that was spoken through the angels
tn.text: The Jews believed that God spoke his law to Moses through angels. This can be stated in active form. AT: "For if the message that God spoke through the angels" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The author is certain that these things are true. AT: "Because the message"
"is certain" or "is true"

tn.ref: every transgression and disobedience receives just punishment
tn.text: Here "transgression" and "disobedience" stand for the people who are guilty of these sins. AT: "every person who sins and disobeys will receive just punishment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These two words mean basically the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: how then can we escape if we ignore so great a salvation?
tn.text: The author uses a question to emphasize that the people will certainly receive punishment if they refuse God's salvation through Christ. AT: "then God will certainly punish us if we do not pay attention to his message about how God will save us!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"do not care for" or "consider unimportant"

tn.ref: This is salvation that was first announced by the Lord
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The Lord himself first announced the message about how God will save us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: and confirmed to us by those who heard it
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "and then those who heard the message confirmed it to us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"in just the way he wanted to do it"
The writer reminds these Hebrew believers that the earth will one day be under the rule of the Lord Jesus.
The quotation here is from the book of Psalms in the Old Testament. It continues on through the next section.

tn.ref: For it was not to the angels that God subjected
tn.text: "For God did not make the angels rulers over"

Here "world" refers to the people who live there. And "to come" means that this is the world in the next age after Christ returns. AT: "the people who will live in the new world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: What is man, that you are mindful of him?
tn.text: This question is used to emphasize that humans are not important enough for God to pay attention them. AT: "No human being is worthy enough for you to think about him!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Or a son of man, that you care for him?
tn.text: This means basically the same thing as the first question. This rhetorical question expresses surprise that humans are not important enough for God to care for them. AT: "No human is worthy enough for you to care for him!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: a little lower than the angels
tn.text: The author speaks of people being less important than angels as if the people are standing in a position that is lower than the angels' position. AT: "less important than the angels" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: made man ... crowned him ... his feet ... to him
tn.text: Here, these phrases do not refer to a specific person but to humans in general, including both males and females. AT: "made humans ... crowned them ... their feet ... to them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_genericnoun]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])

tn.ref: you crowned him with glory and honor
tn.text: The gifts of glory and honor are spoken of as if they were a wreath of leaves placed on the head of a victorious athlete. AT: "you have given them great glory and honor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: You put everything in subjection under his feet
tn.text: The author speaks of humans having control over everything as if they have stepped on everything with their feet. AT: "You have given them control over everything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He did not leave anything not subjected to him
tn.text: This double negative means that all things will be subject to Christ. AT: "God made everything subject to them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: we do not yet see everything subjected to him
tn.text: "we know that humans are not in control of everything yet"

The writer reminds these Hebrew believers that Christ became lower than the angels when he came to earth to suffer death for forgiveness of sins, and that he became a merciful high priest to believers.
"we know there is one"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "whom God made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: lower than the angels ... crowned with glory and honor
tn.text: Translate these as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:heb:02:07|2:7]].
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God crowned him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The experience of death is spoken of as if it were food that was tasted. AT: "has experienced death" or "has died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here, "man" means all people in general, including both males and females. AT: "for every person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
The gift of glory is spoken of here as if it were a place to which people could be brought. AT: "save many sons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here this refers to believers in Christ, including males and females. AT: "many believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])

The author speaks of salvation as if it were a place where Jesus led them. This means Jesus is the person who acted first in order to save others. AT: "the one who saves other people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Becoming mature and completely trained is spoken of as if a person were made complete, perhaps complete in all his body parts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This prophetic quotation comes from a Psalm of King David.
"the one who makes others holy" or "the one who makes others pure from sin"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "those whom he makes holy" or "those whom he makes pure from sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Who that source is can be stated clearly. AT: "have one source, God himself" or "have the same Father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Jesus is not ashamed"

tn.ref: is not ashamed to call them brothers
tn.text: This double negative means that he will claim them as his brothers. AT: "is pleased to call them his brothers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
Here this refers to all who have believed in Jesus, including both men and women. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])

tn.ref: I will proclaim your name to my brothers
tn.text: Here "name" refers to the person's reputation and what they have done. AT: "I will proclaim to my brothers the great things you have done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"when believers come together to worship God"
The prophet Isaiah wrote these quotations.
"And a prophet wrote in another scripture passage what Christ said about God:" (UDB)

tn.ref: the children ... the children of God
tn.text: This speaks about those who believe in Christ as if they were children. AT: "those who are like my children ... those who are like children to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The phrase "flesh and blood" refers to people's human nature. AT: "are all human beings" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Jesus also shared the same things with them
tn.text: "Jesus became human like them"
Here "death" can be stated as a verb. AT: "by dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here "death" can be stated as a verb. AT: "had the power to cause people to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: This was so that he would free all those who through fear of death lived all their lives in slavery
tn.text: The fear of death is spoken of as if it were slavery. Taking away someone's fear is spoken of as it were freeing that person from slavery. AT: "This was so he might free all people. For we lived like slaves because we were afraid of dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Descendants of Abraham are spoken of as if they were his seed. AT: "the descendants of Abraham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"it was necessary for Jesus"
Here "brothers" refers to people in general. AT: "like human beings"

tn.ref: he would bring about the pardon of the people's sins
tn.text: Christ's death on the cross means that God can forgive sins. AT: "he might make it possible for God to forgive people's sins"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Satan tempted him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "whom Satan is tempting" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
